entries.meaning: (now rare) Someone who owns a house as a place of residence; a householder. [from 15th c.]

Someone (traditionally a woman) employed to look after the home, typically by managing domestic servants or superintending household management; also someone with equivalent duties in a hotel, institution etc. [from 16th c.]
examples: She was their third housekeeper, but after a month or so she also gave up.

entries.meaning: Someone who manages the running of a home, traditionally the female head of the household. [from 17th c.]
(colloquial, now rare) Someone who keeps to their house; someone who rarely ventures away from home; an unadventurous person, a homebody. [from 18th c.]
examples: I do assure you he is no house-keeper. I have seen him in desperate conflict with savage men, and even with His Majesty's redcoats.
